column58: I was working on the 4th floor of Old Main in the Office of Undergraduate Education on September 11::: 2001. It started out a beautiful day with clear skies and turned very quickly into a horrible::: scary day. I was at my desk when someone popped in and said a plane hit the 1st building. In my mind I was thinking a small plane and it was an accident. There was a tv in the office down the hall from us...we were glued to it::: along with the rest of the 4th floor::: and saw the 2nd tower hit. We spent the day updating the undergraduate dean offices with Spanier's decision not to cancel classes the rest of that day. Thank you to the Physical Plant employees for hanging the flag! #NeverForget

column6: American Airlines Flight Attendant Jean Roger::: 24::: was murdered when American 11 flew into the WTC. Jean had a degree in Environmental Science from Penn State. Roger was raised in Longmeadow::: Mass.::: where she was a golfer and champion swimmer in high school. As a junior Flight Attendant she was assigned to sit at Boston's airport at 6:30 am to cover any last minute shifts for any coworkers that called out sick that morning. "Someone called in sick and she had to go:::" said her father::: Thomas. She was assigned to Flight 11 at the last minute. Jean spent her last night alive out on the town in Boston celebrating her boyfriend's birthday. She gave him a birthday card. "She wished me to have love::: happiness and peace of mind because really::: everything else just comes and goes:::" her boyfriend said. Despite a late night::: the following morning "she went to work with a smile on her face. She was happy as could be." Due to her last minute assignment to American 11::: her family didn't know she was onboard until 3 hours after the crash.

DYK what is believed to be the oldest continuing education course in the U.S. is none other than the Ice Cream Short Course at Penn State? The course traces its roots to 1892::: when the then-School of Agriculture at the Pennsylvania State College began to offer a class in dairy manufacturing during the winter::: when farmers had less field work and could be spared away from their farms.  Ben and Jerry's is arguably the most famous to participate but other well-known ice cream manufacturers have included Baskin-Robbins::: Hershey::: Mars::: Nestle::: and many others. #NationalIceCreamMonth #ThrowbackThursday

column1: Meteorology is a comparatively young science::: becoming a full-fledged academic department at Penn State in 1954. column165: This is pretty cool...kinda long::: but gotta read the whole story. Wanted to do a large Nittany Lion sand sculpture while at Myrtle Beach::: but couldn't start until late afternoon thanks to a late high tide that day. Normally the late start would not have been an issue::: but we had dinner reservations that night and needed to leave the beach no later than 5PM. I worked as fast as I could::: but after roughly 90 minutes of work I was only about 75% complete and had to abandon the project (I was bummed::: but figured I would just start over the next day). After dinner::: the family decided to take an evening walk on the beach. We figured we would walk by my incomplete Lion to see if any of it still existed. Not only was it still there::: but we were shocked to see that someone had actually finished it! As I was trying to take a picture of the completed lion in the dark::: we heard someone call out "We Are" from just across the beach. It was another family of four (much younger children though)::: and we started talking about the sand sculpture. Turns out the couple (both Penn State alums) had just flown into Myrtle Beach from Latrobe::: PA that afternoon. Although they didn't get in until late afternoon::: the first thing they wanted to do was go down to the beach. When they started walking on the beach::: they were amazed to find a Nittany Lion sculpture in the sands of South Carolina. They saw it wasn't finished::: but noticed it had been "sketched out" in the sand and decided they had to finish digging it out. So thanks to a couple of fellow Penn Staters::: the Nittany Lion sand sculpture was properly finished after all...even got the couple to share a picture of the completed work with me. WE ARE...

Highlighting the Penn State Berkey Creamery and the Penn State College of Agricultural Sciences during #NationalDairyMonth! The very first stand-alone creamery was built in 1889::: and contained a cold-storage room::: a cream-ripening room::: a workroom and space for an office.  During this time::: dairy short courses were offered::: and demand was so high for the courses that milk from local farmers needed to be delivered daily. In 1904::: the creamery moved to what is now the Patterson Building::: and production increased. In addition::: a system of pasteurizing milk was established::: and allowed for delivery of creamery products to retail markets in State College and Altoona. #PennState #ThrowbackThursday

column32: I've gotten concerned messages from friends about the phenomenon of fully vaccinated people getting #covid19. There was dread that the fleeting glimpse of normalcy was a mirage::: the light at the end of the tunnel was from an oncoming train.  Let's talk about that.  These are not 100% effective::: and you all f*cking know that. Don't get stupid on me when you read a scary headline designed to do two things: instill fear and get clicks.  Fully vaccinated people are going to get infected. That's what anything less than 100% effective means. The "best" of these are about 95% effective. Which means that::: give or take::: 1 in 20 may get a mild case if exposed.  Note::: 95% effective is on par with our most effective vaccines.  The measles vaccine is 97% effective. The no-longer available Lyme disease vaccine was 80% effective (and don't you wish that was still available?). Two doses of the chickenpox vaccine is 90% effective. A full course of the polio vaccine is about 99% effective. The pertussis vaccine is 98% effective after a full course of five doses::: but only 73% effective after the first dose::: and immunity can wane without boosters.  So why don't we see news stories all the time about fully vaccinated people getting those diseases? Is it because there's something "better" or more trustworthy about those older vaccines? Is there something "they're not telling us" about the covid vaccine?  No.  It's that we have herd immunity to all those other diseases. Because of vaccines.  When each of those vaccines were rolled out::: there were likely more cases of fully vaccinated people getting sick because there were far more vectors to pass the diseases around. Thanks to herd immunity from the vaccines::: we're not regularly going through pandemics of those diseases anymore.  So yes::: some people are going to get sick when fully vaccinated.  But because of vaccination::: far fewer people will get sick. Those who get sick will get less sick. And the rate of fatality from this virus will drop precipitously.  So will we ever be back to "normal" again? Depends on how you define normal. I'll likely mask up in public as long as it feels right::: even after being fully vaccinated. It's a good way to protect from transmitting other colds and viruses::: and I've grown to like wandering around incognito.  But I'm looking forward to two weeks after my second vaccine. I'm having some friends over to visit who have likewise been vaccinated::: inside::: without our masks on for the first time in over a year. I think you can feel safe doing the same.  It's not normalcy yet::: but it's not an oncoming train.
column33: So then what is the point of the vaccine? Also if they were so preventative how are people still getting it?

Continuing our celebration of #WomensHistoryMonth by honoring Thelma "Mom" Price. Price began her Penn State career at the New Kensington campus in the late 1950s and later became acting director of the Equal Opportunity Program at the University Park campus of Penn State in 1971 and assistant vice president for student affairs in 1972.  Nicknamed ‚ÄúMom:::‚Äù Price often found book money::: food::: housing::: and clothes for students in need. She frequently used her connections to help students obtain internships and full-time employment::: and she actively mentored staff and faculty members. She retired from the University in 1986::: but remained active in the State College community until her death in 2014.

column1: Mary Willard (1898-1993)::: daughter of mathematician Joseph Moody Willard for whom the Willard Building is named::: was a professor of chemistry at Penn State and a pioneer in the field of crime scene investigations. She was regularly called upon to research cases for the Pennsylvania State Police::: other states::: and even Scotland Yard.  She was one of the few women to win every type of award and recognition possible at the time in her fields of microchemistry and crystallography. Willard was a professor for a total of 40 years. #WomensHistoryMonth

The godmother of performing arts at Penn State was Nina Brown::: who directed the Artists Series for almost three decades until her retirement in 1985.  The first season::: which began in 1957 with a performance by soprano Eleanor Steber::: featured appearances by the Cleveland Symphony Orchestra::: American Ballet Theatre and jazz pianist Dave Brubeck. Since then::: the Artists Series and its successor::: the Center for the Performing Arts::: have presented a who‚Äôs who of music::: theater and dance artists from six continents.  During part of its existence::: the Artists Series included distinguished speakers and writers. Brown was particularly proud to have welcomed civil right leader Martin Luther King Jr. and poet Robert Frost. She introduced artist residencies and a Lively Arts for Young Audiences program. She also presented folk and jazz festivals.  In 1999::: Brown received the Center for the Performing Arts Distinguished Service Award. Thank you to the Center for the Performing Arts at Penn State for sharing Nina's story! #TBT #WomensHistoryMonth

column1: Mira Lloyd Dock (1853-1945)::: botanist and environmentalist::: was one of a group of educators and foresters instrumental in the founding of the Pennsylvania State Forest Academy at Mont Alto::: now Penn State Mont Alto.  In 1901::: she was the first woman appointed to a state commission when she began her tenure on the Pennsylvania State Forest Commission. Dock became an influential voice in a small group of foresters advancing the science of conservation and responsible forestry practices in the United States in the early part of the twentieth century.  468 glass lantern slides collected and used by Dock in lectures are housed in the Penn State Mont Alto Campus Library Archives. See the full gallery of photos for some of her slides. #WomensHistoryMonth

column1: During #BlackHistoryMonth and throughout the year::: the University honors Penn Staters like Dr. Guion S. "Guy" Bluford who have made a positive impact on the world. Bluford::: a 1964 #PennState graduate::: became the first African American person in space when he joined the eighth NASA space shuttle mission in 1983.  Subsequently::: he has received multiple awards corresponding to his service as a NASA astronaut and 14 honorary doctorates for his public service work as a leader in aerospace engineering.  In addition to his professional achievements::: Bluford has served as an advocate for inspiring underrepresented groups at both Penn State and on a national level through his service with the Society of Distinguished Alumni and the Committee on Minority Activities. In August 2020::: he spoke at the University's virtual summer commencement ceremony.

Continuing to celebrate #BlackHistoryMonth at PennState: Wally Triplett::: a tailback and linebacker for Penn State Football::: was the first African American to start for the Nittany Lions on Nov. 17::: 1945. In 1946::: the Nittany Lions made history when they refused to play in a game against then-segregated University of Miami.  When told they must leave their black players at home::: the team voted unanimously to cancel the game. The following season::: the question rose again::: and lineman and captain Steve Suhey said::: "We are Penn State:::" adding that there would be no need for any more meetings of that kind.  After his Penn State career::: Triplett became the first African American player to be drafted by and play in the NFL when he was selected by the Detroit Lions in the 19th round of the 1949 NFL Draft.

The class included conversations on patients‚Äô::: families‚Äô::: and medical professionals‚Äô experience of illness and treatment. Also discussions on how an image-based format could bring additional depth and relatability to these stories. column1: The 1987 Penn State Women's Lacrosse team had an outstanding year. Read their story in this #ThrowbackThursday courtesy of the Penn State All-Sports Museum!  https://www.facebook.com/PSUSportsMuseum/photos/a.113672029306/10160466329294307/  Penn State All-Sports Museum January 7::: 2021 at 12:30 PM ¬∑  Today‚Äôs #CollectionSpotlight is the official 1987 Penn State Women‚Äôs Lacrosse team photograph at the Nittany Lion Shrine.  The 1987 Penn State Women‚Äôs Lacrosse team had an outstanding year. Coming back from a heartbreaking defeat in the NCAA Championship game the year before::: our Penn State Nittany Lions put their noses to the grindstone and went 17-2 on the season. One of those losses came to Temple who the Lions would face off against again in the National Championship game. Our women pulled off the 7-6 upset and won their 4th National Championship title. With the loss of key players from the previous season::: Penn State's run to the championship was unexpected and hard earned. The women who did return worked their tails off to be the best they could be and they were rewarded for their efforts. Not only did they win the National Championship::: but 5 players were named to the All-America team. Mary McCarthy::: Amanda Veal and Chris Vitale earned first team honors while Beth Stokes and Tami Worley brought home second team honors.  The passion::: dedication::: and resilience of the 1987 team is remembered in this photograph. A talented group of women who came out on top and brought home their glory to Penn State.  If you have an interest in supporting the Museum during our closure::: text PSASM to 41444::: or give online here: igfn.us

column12: The COVID loss of taste and smell is different than your typical cold/sinus infection. I first experienced a distortion (everything smelled of stinky feet or earwax ü§¢) followed by complete loss of smell 2 days later (though I could detect salty::: sour::: and a little sweet but not the flavor). It was about 2-3 weeks before about 30% my smell and taste returned. It‚Äôs been almost 2 months and things still do not smell and taste like they used to...cannot taste the depth of flavors...it‚Äôs rather sad. ‚òπÔ∏è Amazing how complex our sense of smell and taste is. I‚Äôm sure it takes quite and orchestra of nerve cells to fully taste and smell::: from your brain to your nose to your tongue. ü§Ø And yes I did test + a week after symptoms started. Had a negative test 2 days before symptoms.

WATCH.PSU.EDU Penn State - Veterans Day Live Stream Events  WPSU 11 November 2020 –≥.::: 08:44 ¬∑  Today is Veterans Day! Join the Penn State Veteran the Penn State Student Veteran Organization as they host a livestream event of the annual Veteran‚Äôs Day Ceremony to honor and thank all who served in the U.S. armed forces.  To view the ceremony online::: which will start at 11:00 a.m.::: visit watch.psu.edu/MAW.  (Please note: The event will not take place in person at Old Main on the University Park campus this year.)

On Veterans Day::: we honor all #PennState community members who have served in the United States Military. Read President Barron's Veterans Day blog::: "Protect::: serve and celebrate!"::: at https://diggingdeeper.psu.edu/2020/11/protect-serve-and-celebrate/  Pictured here is the Veterans Plaza::: with the curved wall named to honor Lt. Michael P. Murphy::: a member of the class of 1998 and the first University alumnus to be awarded the Medal of Honor.  The curved wall bears the inscription of a Greek phrase::: believed to have been spoken by Spartan mothers to their sons before battle::: meaning::: ‚ÄúWith it [your shield]::: or on it." According to ancient Spartan tradition::: a warrior was never without his shield -- he either returned home from battle alive::: carrying his shield::: or dead::: carried upon it by his comrades.

column23: As a committed mask wearer::: I have to say this is such a horrible ad. Of all the other ways they could have encouraged mask wearing::: especially at a time when a multitude of PSU parents are weighing whether or not the tuition is worth it when students are not getting in person instruction they had initially signed up for... This ad campaign is poorly done. They could have said something more inviting. Or something encouraging or that inspires courage and persistence. But this? It's a turn off. The tone is all wrong. Hardly a 'Welcome Back::: O' students who are paying tens of thousands of dollars!". Everyone gets the mask thing. This kind of tone will only evoke feelings of resistance in the age group you're dealing with. Rethinking this ad campaign might be wise. Try something LIKE::: "What is sexier than intelligence?? Intelligence behind a mask. Ask any superhero.". Something like that. Cheeky. Inviting. Light-hearted. Doom and gloom and thinly-veiled threats never won the hearts of masses. Just re-think the way you send the message. Attract with honey::: not vinegar.

column7: Of course::: none of this would have been necessary had the administration done the sensible and humane thing::: and kept classes virtual for fall semester. We're left with a reopening plan that has an excellent chance of failure::: and when it fails the community will be left to deal with the consequences-\-\t he students might not be on campus anymore once it shuts down::: but they'll still be in town::: unsupervised::: in numbers great enough to form super-spreader events. Containing the virus by controlling on-campus behavior was never a plausible scenario::: because 65% of the student body lives::: shops::: parties::: drinks::: and spends the bulk of its time OFF-campus. Even the minority who live on-campus shop and drink and party off-campus. If the virus gets loose among this cohort::: and there's every reason to believe that it will::: people will die who did not have to die. And that will be on the heads of those who decided to bring all the students back in the midst of a raging pandemic. They can try to blame the students::: they can try to fob it off on the municipal entities (whose ability to control resident behavior is limited by law)::: but the responsibility for what happens now is all theirs. It stems from a decision they::: and they alone::: made. They're prepping for a disaster entirely of their own making.
